syllabus.title: Rational Numbers
syllabus.overview: This chapter introduces Rational Numbers and their properties (closure, commutativity, associativity), teaching how to perform operations and represent them on a number line.
keyTopics: Rational Numbers between two Rational Numbers

formulas.name: Standard form
formulas.formula: p/q where p, q are integers and q ≠ 0

examTips: Finding rational numbers between two given numbers using the LCM method is a very common question.
Remember that 0 is a rational number, but division by 0 is not defined.
Questions on writing the additive/multiplicative inverse are guaranteed 1-mark questions.

syllabus.title: Linear Equations in One Variable
syllabus.overview: Focuses on solving linear equations where the highest power of the variable is 1, and heavily emphasizes translating real-world problems into algebraic equations.
keyTopics: Solving Equations with Variable on one side
Solving Equations with Variable on both sides
examTips: Word problems involving ages (e.g., '10 years ago, father was 3 times...') are excellent 4-mark questions.
In 2-digit number problems, remember the number is represented as 10y + x (where x is units digit, y is tens digit).
Always verify your answer by substituting the value of the variable back into the original equation.

syllabus.title: Understanding Quadrilaterals
syllabus.overview: Introduces polygons and dives deep into the properties of various quadrilaterals like parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares.
keyTopics: Polygons (Convex vs Concave, Regular vs Irregular)
examTips: You must know the distinction between the properties of a Rhombus (all sides equal, diagonals bisect at 90°) and a Rectangle (all angles 90°, diagonals equal).
Using the sum of exterior angles = 360° is the fastest way to find the number of sides of a regular polygon.

syllabus.title: Data Handling
syllabus.overview: Teaches organizing and presenting data visually. Focuses significantly on Pie Charts and introduces the basic concept of Probability.

formulas.name: Probability
formulas.formula: Number of favorable outcomes / Total outcomes

examTips: Drawing a Pie Chart requires calculating the central angle correctly. Make a table first!
Probability questions in Class 8 are basic (coins, dice, colorful balls in a bag).
A tally mark table is usually a 2-mark or 3-mark question.

syllabus.title: Squares and Square Roots
syllabus.overview: Covers finding squares, properties of squares, and methods of finding square roots (Prime Factorisation and Long Division).
keyTopics: Finding the Square of a Number

formulas.name: Pythagorean Triplet
formulas.formula: For m > 1, the triplet is 2m, m² - 1, m² + 1

formulas.name: Sum of First n Odd Nos

examTips: The Long Division method is crucial and takes practice. Step 1: Pair the digits from the decimal point.
Questions asking 'What is the smallest number by which X should be multiplied to make it a perfect square?' require the Prime Factorisation method.
Questions asking 'What is the smallest number that should be subtracted from X to make it a perfect square?' require the Long Division method.

syllabus.title: Cubes and Cube Roots
syllabus.overview: Extends the concepts from Chapter 5 to cubes and cube roots, focusing primarily on the prime factorisation method.
examTips: Remember that the cube of an even number is even, and the cube of an odd number is odd.
Memorize cubes from 1 to 10. It speeds up calculations significantly.
The prime factorisation of a perfect cube must have factors grouped in triplets (groups of 3). If a prime number is not part of a triplet, the main number is not a perfect cube.

syllabus.title: Comparing Quantities
syllabus.overview: A heavily application-based chapter involving ratios, percentages, discount, profit & loss, tax/VAT, and Compound Interest.
keyTopics: Prices related to Buying and Selling (Profit/Loss, Tax/VAT/GST)
examTips: Discount is always calculated on the Marked Price (MP), while Profit/Loss is always calculated on the Cost Price (CP).
For 'compounded half-yearly' problems, halve the Rate (R/2) and double the Time (2n).
Population growth/depreciation problems use the Compound Interest formula.

syllabus.title: Algebraic Expressions and Identities
syllabus.overview: Focuses on the multiplication of algebraic expressions (monomials, binomials, polynomials) and introduces standard algebraic identities.
keyTopics: Addition and Subtraction of Algebraic Expressions
examTips: Memorize the 4 standard identities. They form the basis of factorisation in Chapter 12 and algebra in Class 9/10.
Questions like 'Evaluate 103 × 104 using suitable identity' are extremely common. (Hint: Use Identity 4 with x=100, a=3, b=4).

syllabus.title: Mensuration
syllabus.overview: Extends area/perimeter to shapes like trapeziums and general quadrilaterals, and introduces Surface Area and Volume of 3D solids (Cube, Cuboid, Cylinder).
keyTopics: Area of General Quadrilaterals and Special Polygons
Surface Area of Cube, Cuboid, and Cylinder
Volume of Cube, Cuboid, and Cylinder
examTips: Read carefully if the question asks for Total Surface Area (TSA) or Lateral/Curved Surface Area (LSA/CSA). An open box has no top lid!
Volume is the amount a container can hold (Capacity). 1 m³ = 1000 Litres, 1 Litre = 1000 cm³.
To find the area of an irregular polygon field, divide it into triangles and trapeziums based on a diagonal.

syllabus.title: Exponents and Powers
syllabus.overview: Introduces negative exponents and standard form notation for expressing very large and very small numbers.
keyTopics: Use of Exponents to Express Small Numbers in Standard Form
examTips: Standard form has exactly one non-zero digit before the decimal point: m × 10ⁿ, where 1 ≤ m < 10.
Moving the decimal point to the right results in a negative exponent (e.g., 0.0034 = 3.4 × 10⁻³).
Always convert expressions to have positive exponents in your final answer unless asked otherwise.

syllabus.title: Direct and Inverse Proportions
syllabus.overview: Explores relations where an increase in one quantity causes a corresponding increase (Direct) or decrease (Inverse) in another.
examTips: Cost and Quantity = Direct. Speed and Time = Inverse. Workers and Days = Inverse.
First, create a table with two rows (e.g., Workers and Days). Identifying if it's Direct or Inverse is 50% of the battle.

syllabus.title: Factorisation
syllabus.overview: The reverse of algebraic multiplication — converting an expression into a product of factors using common factors, regrouping, or identities.
examTips: Always look for the greatest common factor (GCF) FIRST before applying any identities or splitting the middle term.
Identity a² - b² = (a-b)(a+b) is the most heavily tested factorization concept.
In division problems, factorise the numerator first, and usually, the denominator will cancel out with one of the factors.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Graphs
syllabus.overview: Introduces coordinate geometry basics and focuses on reading and drawing line graphs linking dependent and independent variables.
examTips: A 'Linear Graph' is a straight, unbroken line connecting points. A 'Line Graph' can be jagged (connecting different line segments).
Remember that the x-axis typically represents the independent variable (like Time), and the y-axis represents the dependent variable (like Distance or Temperature).
